title: Conjugate Generators of Knot and Link Groups

title_detail.value: Conjugate Generators of Knot and Link Groups

summary:
This note shows that if two elements of equal trace (e.g., conjugate
elements) generate an arithmetic two-bridge knot or link group, then the
elements are parabolic. This includes the figure-eight knot and Whitehead link
groups. Similarly, if two conjugate elements generate the trefoil knot group,
then the elements are peripheral.

summary_detail.value:
This note shows that if two elements of equal trace (e.g., conjugate
elements) generate an arithmetic two-bridge knot or link group, then the
elements are parabolic. This includes the figure-eight knot and Whitehead link
groups. Similarly, if two conjugate elements generate the trefoil knot group,
then the elements are peripheral.

author: Jason Callahan
arxiv_comment: 10 pages, submitted to Journal of Knot Theory and Its Ramifications
fulltext:
arXiv:0806.3452v2 [math.GT] 16 Jan 2009

CONJUGATE GENERATORS OF KNOT AND LINK GROUPS
JASON CALLAHAN

Abstract. This note shows that if two elements of equal trace (e.g., conjugate elements) generate an arithmetic two-bridge knot or link group, then the
elements are parabolic. This includes the figure-eight knot and Whitehead link
groups. Similarly, if two conjugate elements generate the trefoil knot group,
then the elements are peripheral.

1. Introduction
By a knot or link group, we will mean the fundamental group of the knot or
link complement in S 3 . It is well known that a two-bridge knot or link group
is generated by two meridians of the knot or link (see [5]). The converse is also
known; it is proved for link complements in S 3 in [4] (Corollary 3.3), for hyperbolic
3-manifolds of finite volume in [1] (Theorem 4.3), and for the most general class of
3-manifolds in [3] (Corollary 5):
Theorem 1.1. If M is a compact, orientable, irreducible 3-manifold with incompressible boundary and π1 M is generated by two peripheral elements, then M is
homeomorphic to the exterior of a two-bridge knot or link in S 3 .
Arising from work on Simon's Conjecture (see Section 6 for statement and Problem 1.12 of [11]), A. Reid and others proposed the following conjecture, which for
convenience we will call:
Reid's Conjecture. Let K be a knot for which π1 (S 3 r K) is generated by two
conjugate elements. Then the elements are peripheral (and hence the knot is twobridge by above).
A knot in S 3 is a hyperbolic, satellite, or torus knot (Corollary 2.5 of [18]). By
Proposition 17 of [8], the (p, q)-torus knot group can be generated by two conjugate
elements only when p = 2, i.e., when the torus knot is two-bridge. In Section 5,
we establish Reid's Conjecture for the (2, 3)-torus knot group (i.e., the trefoil knot
group), and we prove in Section 6 that Reid's Conjecture implies Simon's Conjecture
for two-bridge knots. The latter conjecture has recently been proved in [2].
When a knot or link complement in S 3 is hyperbolic, peripheral elements such
as meridians map to parabolic elements under the discrete faithful representation
of the knot or link group into PSL2 C. Conjugate elements have equal trace, and
we prove in Section 3 a stronger version of Reid's Conjecture for the figure-eight
knot (whose complement in S 3 is well known to be hyperbolic by [16]):
Theorem 1.2. If two elements of equal trace generate the figure-eight knot group,
then the elements are parabolic.
The figure-eight knot group can, however, be generated by three conjugate loxodromic elements, so this result is, in some sense, sharp.
1

 2

JASON CALLAHAN

The proof of Theorem 1.2 relies heavily on the arithmeticity of the figure-eight
knot complement in S 3 . Since the figure-eight knot is the only knot with arithmetic
hyperbolic complement in S 3 ([13]), extending our result to all hyperbolic knot
groups would require new techniques. By Section 5 of [6], however, there are exactly
four arithmetic Kleinian groups generated by two parabolic elements; each is the
fundamental group of a hyperbolic two-bridge knot or link complement in S 3 : the
figure-eight knot, the Whitehead link, and the links 622 and 623 . In Section 4, we
again exploit arithmeticity to extend our result to these:
Theorem 1.3. If two elements of equal trace generate an arithmetic two-bridge
knot or link group, then the elements are parabolic.
2. Preliminaries
We collect several preliminary results that will be useful in what follows. The
first is Lemma 7.1, together with the comments and definitions that precede it, in
[7].
Lemma 2.1. Let Γ be a finite-covolume Kleinian group whose traces lie in R,
the ring of integers in Q(trΓ). If hX, Y i is a non-elementary subgroup of Γ, then
O = R[1, X, Y, XY ] is an order in the quaternion algebra

over Q(trΓ). Its discriminant d(O) is the ideal h2 − tr[X, Y ]i in R.
The second is Theorem 6.3.4 in [12].
Theorem 2.2. Let O1 and O2 be orders in a quaternion algebra over a number
field. If O1 ⊂ O2 , then d(O2 ) | d(O1 ), and O1 = O2 if and only if d(O1 ) = d(O2 ).
Our application is the following.
Corollary 2.3. Let Γ be a finite-covolume Kleinian group whose traces lie in R,
the ring of integers in Q(trΓ). If hA, Bi = Γ = hX, Y i, then 2 − tr[X, Y ] is a unit
multiple of 2 − tr[A, B] in R.
Proof. By Lemma 2.1, O1 = R[1, A, B, AB] and O2 = R[1, X, Y, XY ] are orders in
AΓ. Furthermore, d(O1 ) = h2 − tr[A, B]i and d(O2 ) = h2 − tr[X, Y ]i are ideals in
R. The Cayley-Hamilton Theorem yields the identity
X + X −1 = trX * 1
which implies A−1 , B −1 ∈ O1 and X −1 , Y −1 ∈ O2 . Since O1 and O2 are ideals
that are also rings with 1, we have
Γ = hA, Bi ⊂ O1 and Γ = hX, Y i ⊂ O2 .
Clearly, R ⊂ O1 , O2 , so RΓ ⊆ O1 , O2 , and O1 , O2 ⊆ RΓ by definition. Therefore,
O1 = RΓ = O2 .
Hence, d(O1 ) = d(O2 ) by Theorem 2.2, and the result follows.
We conclude with two technical lemmas.

3. The Figure-Eight Knot
The discrete faithful representation of the figure-eight knot group
π1 (S 3 r K) = ha, b | a−1 bab−1 a = ba−1 bab−1 i

(see [16]). Note our mild abuse of notation which will be continued tacitly throughout: we blur the distinction between elements of PSL2 C and their lifts to SL2 C.
Then Γ = hA, Bi is a finite-covolume Kleinian subgroup of PSL2 (Z[ω]), so trΓ ⊂
Z[ω], the ring of integers in the trace field Q(ω). The invariant quaternion algebra
is M2 (Q(ω)). Theorem 1.2 follows immediately from:
Theorem 3.1. If Γ = hX, Y i with trX = trY , then X and Y are parabolic.
Proof. By Corollary 2.3, 2 − tr[X, Y ] is a unit multiple of 2 − tr[A, B] = −ω 2 in

4. The Arithmetic Two-Bridge Links

where ξ = 1 + i, 1 + ω, and θ for the Whitehead link and the links 622 and 623
respectively (see Section 5 of [6]). Then Γ = hA, Bi is a finite-covolume Kleinian
group whose traces lie in Z[i], Z[ω], and Z[θ] respectively. These are the rings
of integers in the respective trace fields Q(i), Q(ω), and Q(θ). The respective
invariant quaternion algebras are M2 (Q(i)), M2 (Q(ω)), and M2 (Q(θ)). We now
establish Theorem 1.3 for each arithmetic two-bridge link group.
Theorem 4.1. Let Γ be the discrete faithful representation in PSL2 (Z[i]) of the
Whitehead link group with notation as above. If Γ = hX, Y i with trX = trY , then
X and Y are parabolic.
Proof. By Corollary 2.3, 2 − tr[X, Y ] is a unit multiple of 2 − tr[A, B] = −2i in Z[i].
Since (Z[i])∗ = {±1, ±i} and tr[X, Y ] 6∈ (−2, 2),

y ∈ {1, ±i, ±(1 + i), ±(1 − i), 2, ±2i}.

We now check which of these values have the form x2 = a2 − b2 + 2abi ∈ Z[i]
based on 0, ±1, ±2, and ±3 being the only imaginary parts that arise in the table.
Case 1: The imaginary part of x2 is 0; that is,
2ab = 0 =⇒ a = 0 or b = 0
=⇒ x2 = −b2 or x2 = a2 ∈ Z2
The only value in the table with imaginary part 0 that can be expressed in
either of these forms is x2 = 4, i.e., X and Y are parabolic.
Case 2: The imaginary part of x2 is ±1; that is, 2ab = ±1, which is impossible for a, b ∈ Z. Hence, x2 cannot have imaginary part ±1.
Case 3: The imaginary part of x2 is ±2; that is,
2ab = ±2

=⇒ a2 = b2 = 1
=⇒ x2 = ±2i

But ±2i does not appear in the table, so x2 cannot have imaginary part
±2.
Case 4: The imaginary part of x2 is ±3; that is, 2ab = ±3, which is impossible for a, b ∈ Z. Hence, x2 cannot have imaginary part ±3.
This exhausts the table of possible values for x2 ; therefore, X and Y must be
parabolic if they are to generate Γ and have equal trace.

Theorem 4.2. Let Γ be the discrete faithful representation in PSL2 (Z[ω]) of the
622 link group with notation as before. If Γ = hX, Y i with trX = trY , then X and
Y are parabolic.
Proof. By Corollary 2.3, 2 − tr[X, Y ] is a unit multiple of 2 − tr[A, B] = −3ω in
Z[ω]. Since tr[X, Y ] 6∈ (−2, 2), we have
2 − tr[X, Y ] ∈ {±3ω, ±3(1 − ω), −3} ⊂ 3(Z[ω])∗ .
Let
x = trX = trY = a + bω ∈ Z[ω], y = trXY − 2, and z = 2 − tr[X, Y ].
Lemma 2.4 implies y | z, and hence y | 3, in Z[ω]. Therefore, since trXY 6∈ (−2, 2),
we have
y ∈ {±(3 − 3ω), ±(2 − ω), ±(1 + ω), ±(1 − ω), ±(1 − 2ω), ±ω, ±3ω, 1, 3}.


5. Torus Knots
Throughout this section, we assume gcd(p, q) = 1 and 2 ≤ p < q. As is well
known, the (p, q)-torus knot group admits the presentation
π1 (S 3 r Kp,q ) = hc, d | cp = dq i,
which clearly surjects Zp ∗ Zq = hs, t | sp = tq = 1i via c 7→ s, d 7→ t (see [5]).
We begin our investigation of conjugate generators for torus knot groups by
paraphrasing Proposition 17 of [8]:
Proposition 5.1. If Zp ∗Zq = hs, t | sp = tq = 1i can be generated by two conjugate
elements, then p = 2.
Thus, via the surjection above, the (p, q)-torus knot group can be generated by
two conjugate elements only when p = 2, i.e., when the torus knot is two-bridge
with normal form (q/1). The (2, q)-torus knot group hc, d | c2 = dq i has a parabolic
representation into PSL2 C generated by




0
(2 cos(π/q))−1
1 − 4 cos2 (π/q) 1
c 7→ C =
and d 7→ D =
−2 cos(π/q)
0
−4 cos2 (π/q) 1
(Theorem 6 of [15]). Then Γq = hC, Di is a finite-coarea subgroup of PSL2 R and
has a presentation hC, D | C 2 = Dq = 1i = Z2 ∗ Zq . Furthermore, the traces of Γq
are algebraic integers in Q(trΓ) = Q(cos(π/q)) (cf. Section 8.3 of [12]).
To analyze the case q = 3 (i.e., the trefoil knot), we recall the classification of
generating pairs for the groups Zp ∗ Zq up to Nielsen equivalence (Corollary 4.14 of
[20] and Theorem 13 of [8]):
Theorem 5.2. Every generating pair for the group Zp ∗ Zq = hs, t | sp = tq = 1i is
Nielsen equivalent to exactly one generating pair of the form (sm , tn ) where
gcd(m, p) = gcd(n, q) = 1, 0 < 2m ≤ p, and 0 < 2n ≤ q.
Corollary 5.3. If two conjugate elements generate the (2, 3)-torus knot group (i.e.,
the trefoil knot group), then the elements are peripheral.

 CONJUGATE GENERATORS OF KNOT AND LINK GROUPS

9

Proof. Suppose hα, βi = π1 (S 3 r K2,3 ) with α conjugate to β. Let α 7→ X and
β 7→ Y via the representation above. Then hX, Y i = Γ3 = Z2 ∗ Z3 , and X is
conjugate to Y , so trX = trY . Thus, by Theorem 5.2 with p = 2 and q = 3, (X, Y )
is Nielsen equivalent to (C, D). Since commutators of Nielsen equivalent pairs have
equal trace, we have
2 − tr[X, Y ] = 2 − tr[C, D] = −1.
Lemma 2.4 then implies trXY − 2 = ±1, and so tr2 X = tr2 Y = 4. Hence, α and
β are peripheral.

As defined in this section, Γq is a discrete faithful representation into PSL2 R
of the (2, q, ∞)-triangle group. Thus, the proof of Corollary 5.3 shows that if two
elements of equal trace (e.g., conjugate elements) generate the (2, 3, ∞)-triangle
group (i.e., the modular group), then the elements are parabolic. Following Section
13.3 of [12] (cf. [17]), the (2, q, ∞)-triangle group is arithmetic only when q = 3,
4, 6, or ∞. Similar methods can then be used to show that if two elements of
equal trace generate an arithmetic (2, q, ∞)-triangle group, then the elements are
parabolic. The (2, q, ∞)-triangle group can, however, be generated by two conjugate
hyperbolic elements when q > 3 is odd: with Γq = hC, Di as above, let X = CD
q+1
and Y = C −1 XC = DC; then (Y X) 2 = D, so hX, Y i = Γq , and trX = trY =
−4 cos(π/q) < −2 since q > 3, so X and Y are hyperbolic.
6. Simon's Conjecture
The following is attributed to J. Simon (cf. Problem 1.12 of [11]).
Simon's Conjecture. A knot group can surject only finitely many other knot
groups.
To show Reid's Conjecture implies Simon's Conjecture for two-bridge knots, we
first note Theorem 5.2 of [14] (recall that a knot complement is called small if it
does not contain a closed embedded essential surface):
Theorem 6.1. If M is a small hyperbolic knot complement in S 3 , then there
exist only finitely many hyperbolic 3-manifolds N for which there is a peripheral
preserving epimorphism π1 M ։ π1 N .
Theorem 6.2. Reid's Conjecture implies Simon's Conjecture for two-bridge knots.
Proof. Let K be a two-bridge knot and φi : π1 (S 3 r K) ։ π1 (S 3 r Ki ) a collection
of epimorphisms φi and knots Ki .
If Ki is a (p, q)-torus knot, then its Alexander polynomial has degree (p−1)(q−1)
and divides the Alexander polynomial of K since φi is an epimorphism (see [5]).
This can occur for only finitely many integer pairs (p, q); hence, only finitely many
Ki are torus knots.
Now assume Ki is not a torus knot. Since K is two-bridge, π1 (S 3 r K) is
generated by two conjugate meridians, a and b. Then φi (a) and φi (b) are conjugate
elements that generate π1 (S 3 r Ki ), so Reid's Conjecture implies that they are
peripheral. Hence, by Theorem 1.1, Ki is two-bridge and therefore hyperbolic since
it is not a torus knot.
Let λ ∈ π1 (S 3 rK) such that ha, λi is a peripheral subgroup of π1 (S 3 rK). Then
λ commutes with a in π1 (S 3 r K), so φi (λ) commutes with φi (a) in π1 (S 3 r Ki )
and hence is a peripheral element of π1 (S 3 r Ki ). Therefore, φi is peripheral

 10

JASON CALLAHAN

preserving, so the result follows from Theorem 6.1 since hyperbolic two-bridge knot
complements in S 3 are small ([9]).
